sections.title: What is the Nebulang App Translator?

content.body:
The **Nebulang App Translator** is a Bubble plugin designed to translate your application content dynamically, without changing URLs, reloading pages, or breaking your existing workflows.

Unlike traditional translation approaches that rely on page redirects or static language versions, this plugin works directly on the rendered DOM, allowing real-time language switching with full control over what should â€” or should not â€” be translated.

Managing multi-language applications in Bubble often requires:

- Duplicated pages

- Complex conditionals

- External redirection logic

- SEO compromises

> This plugin eliminates that complexity by offering a **client-side translation layer**, enabling you to translate content instantly while preserving your app structure.

This plugin is ideal for:
- SaaS platforms targeting international users
- Landing pages with multi-language support
- Marketplaces and dashboards
- Apps that require language switching without page reloads

sections.title: What this plugin does not do

content.body:
To avoid misunderstandings, it's important to clarify:
- It does **not** create separate language pages
- It does **not** change your app URLs
- It does **not** automatically translate database content unless rendered on the page

1. The plugin detects the current page language
2. A language selector allows the user to switch languages
3. The plugin translates visible text nodes dynamically
4. Protected elements (using `no-translate`) are ignored
1. Events and states expose the selected language to Bubble workflows

This section will guide you through the initial setup of the plugin, ensuring you can get it up and running quickly and correctly inside your Bubble application.
The goal here is not just installation, but achieving a **first successful and functional setup**, so you can confidently continue configuring and customizing the plugin.

To install the plugin, follow these steps:
1. Open your Bubble application editor
2. Navigate to the **Plugins** tab
3. Click on **Add plugins**
4. Search for the plugin name in the Bubble Plugin Marketplace
5. Click **Install**
Once installed, the plugin will be available globally in your application and ready to be configured.
> ðŸ’¡ TipÂ Â 
> You do not need to reinstall the plugin when switching environments (Development / Live). Bubble handles this automatically.

sections.title: Adding the Plugin to the Page

content.body:
Depending on the plugin type, one of the following will apply:
- **Element-based plugin**Â Â 
Â  The plugin will appear in the **Visual Elements** panel and can be dragged onto any page or reusable element.
- **Non-element plugin**Â Â 
Â  The plugin runs globally and does not require placing an element on the page. Configuration is handled entirely through plugin settings and workflows.
Make sure the plugin is present (or initialized) on every page where its functionality is expected to work.

Before the plugin can work correctly, a minimal setup is required.
At this stage, you should:
- Open the plugin configuration panel
- Review the default values
- Set only the fields required for basic functionality
The plugin is designed to work out-of-the-box with sensible defaults, allowing you to test it without advanced configuration.
> âš ï¸ ImportantÂ Â 
> Avoid over-customizing at this stage. The goal is to confirm that the plugin works as expected before applying visual or advanced settings.

After installation and minimal configuration, perform a quick test:

1. Preview your app
2. Interact with the plugin (or the UI element it controls)
3. Confirm that:
Â  Â - The plugin initializes correctly
Â  Â - No console errors are displayed
Â  Â - The expected behavior occurs

If the plugin exposes **states or events**, verify that:
- States are updating as expected
- Events are being triggered at the correct time

This confirms that the plugin is properly installed and connected to Bubbleâ€™s runtime.

When getting started, avoid these common issues:
- Forgetting to place the element on the page (for element-based plugins)
- Testing only in the editor instead of Preview mode
- Expecting database content to update automatically without workflows
- Applying advanced settings before validating the basic setup
Taking a few minutes to validate the initial setup will save significant time later.

Now that the plugin is installed and working:
- Proceed to the **Configuration** tab to customize behavior and appearance
- Explore **Events and States** to integrate the plugin into workflows
- Review **Advanced Usage** once the core setup is stable
